journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Influence of tool rotation speed and feed rate on the forming limit of friction stir welded AA6061-T6 sheets

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science Bangalore, India

author-notes.corresp: R Ganesh Narayanan, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati 781039, India. Email: ganu@iitg.ernet.in

abstract.p: In this study, the influence of tool rotation speed and feed rate on the forming limit of friction stir welded Al 6061-T651 sheets has been investigated. The forming limit curve was evaluated by limit dome height test performed on all the friction stir welded sheets. The welding trials were conducted at a tool rotation speed of 1300 and 1400 r/min and feed rate of 90 and 100 mm/min. A third trial of welding was performed at a rotational speed of 1500 r/min and feed rate 120 mm/min. It is found that with increase in the tool rotation speed, from 1300 to 1400 r/min, for a constant feed rate, the forming limit of friction stir welded blank has improved and with increase in feed rate, from 90 to 100 mm/min, for a constant tool rotation speed, it has decreased. The forming limit of friction stir welded sheets is better than unwelded sheets. The thickness gradient after forming is severe in the cases of friction stir welded blanks made at higher feed rate and lower rotation speed. The strain hardening exponent of weld (n) increases with increase in tool rotation speed and it decreases with increase in feed rate. It has been demonstrated that the change in the forming limit of friction stir welded sheets with respect to welding parameters is due to the thickness distribution severity and strain hardening exponent of the weld region during forming. There is not much variation in the dome height among the friction stir welded sheets tested. When compared with unwelded sheets, dome height of friction stir welded sheets is higher in near-plane-strain condition, but it is lesser in stretching strain paths.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Friction stir welding (FSW) is a novel joining process for non-ferrous materials used for fabricating good quality joints without any defects. This is a complex process; it has many process parameters on which the weld quality depends. The main parameters are tool materials and its configuration, feed rate (FR), tool rotation speed (TRS), axial force, and workpiece materials. In this, the tool shape determines the heating, plastic flow, and forging pattern of the weld region metal and hence the weld morphology.1,2 TRS is one of the main factors affecting the frictional heat. If the rotating speed is too low, the frictional heat is not enough to induce a plasticized flow and this leads to defects in the weld. Along with an increase in the rotating speed, the frictional heat also increases. When the rotating speed reaches a certain limit, the possibilities of defect formation decreases. Another main factor is the FR. The temperature in the weld region is controlled by the FR. When the FR is low, the temperature rise would be higher as the heat input to a given control volume of material would be for a longer time. On the other hand, when the FR is too large, the frictional heat is not enough to plasticize the materials beneath the tool shoulder and around the probe, resulting in improper welding.1,2 So both TRS and FR are responsible for frictional heat to deliver perfect defect-free welds. Once the appropriate welding parameters are established along with downward force and penetration depth of the tool, they can produce the best weld quality with improved microstructure and mechanical properties.

Most of the studies on FSW blanks are focused on the experimental studies to understand the process, for example, the effect of process parameters such as tool geometry, tool materials, rotation speed, FR, tool angle, base material quality and their arrangement on the advancing or retreating sides. The quality of welding is quantified by the temperature distribution, material flow, microstructure, mechanical properties, hardness, residual stress, defects, and texture in the welded area. A few important investigations describing the influence of welding parameters on the microstructure, mechanical properties, weld formation, and temperature distribution on 6xxx aluminum alloy FSW joints are discussed here. Ericsson and Sandstrom3 investigated the effect of fatigue strength of FSW joints made of AA6082 in T6 and T4 temper conditions influenced by FR and also compared the results with conventional arc-welding methods such as MIG-pulse and TIG. In this study, they made FSWs at FRs 700 and 1400 mm/min and rotational speeds of 2500 r/min and 2200 r/min. From their results, it is found that FR has no major influence on the mechanical and fatigue properties of the FSWs. At a significantly lower FR, the fatigue performance was improved. Similar studies were performed by other research groups and are presented in Table 1 as a summary. Table 1.
Summary on the influence of rotation speed and FR on the performance of FSW joints.

FR: feed rate; FSW: friction stir welding; SD, shoulder diameter; PD, pin diameter; PL, pin length; TRS, tool rotation speed; YS: yield strength; BM: base metal; LDH: limit dome height; HAZ: heat-affected zone; WN weld nugget; and TWB: tailor-welded blank.

Recently, Janaki Ramulu et al.19 conducted a preliminary investigation on the effect of TRS and FR on the formability of FSW sheets. It is understood from the discussion made that most of the studies are aimed at analyzing the influence of FSW parameters on the mechanical behavior of FSW blanks characterized by tensile tests. These studies are focused on investigating the evolution of mechanical properties, microstructure, and defects with respect to the FSW parameters. A few studies are focused on the formability of FSW blanks, mainly on their forming limit, failure location, and prediction accuracy. The dependence of formability (say forming limit) on the FSW parameters, namely, FR, transverse speed, SD, plunge depth, etc., are not studied and critically analyzed. These parameters are expected to change the weld zone properties significantly as the tensile tests indicate and hence the overall formability of FSW sheets.

The main aim of this study is to analyze the influence of TRS and FR on the forming limit of FSW sheets. The impact of above-mentioned parameters on the thickness distribution and dome height is also described. The forming limit variation with respect to thinning severity of FSW blanks and strain hardening exponent of the weld region is presented. The forming limit only on the stretching side of the forming limit diagram (FLD) was evaluated by the LDH test.

sec.title: Base material properties
sec.p: Aluminum alloy 6061-T651 of 2.1 mm thickness is used for the welding experiments. It is formable enough to manufacture stamped parts. Base metals (BMs) with same thicknesses are welded throughout this study. The nominal chemical composition of the base material (in wt%) is given as: Si: 0.65, Fe: 0.3, Cu: 0.27, Mn: 0.02, Mg: 1.0, Cr: 0.17, Zn: 0.04, Ti: 0.02, and Al: balance.

The mechanical properties and plastic strain ratio (R) were evaluated through tensile tests as per the ASTM-B557M and ASTM-E517 standards. The mechanical properties of the base material were measured in different directions with respect to the rolling directions of the sheet such as: 0°, 15°, 30°, 45°, 60°, 75°, and 90°. The standard procedure was followed to evaluate all the mechanical properties from the load-progression data obtained from the machine.20 Table 2 presents the mechanical properties of AA6061-T651 base material used in this study. Table 2.
Tensile properties of AA6061-T651 at room temperature.
Mechanical properties Rolling direction
0° 15° 30° 45° 60° 75° 90°

UTS (MPa) 304 ± 2 317 ± 6 300 ± 3 290 ± 5 300 ± 9 313 ± 7 304 ± 4
UE (%) 9.2 8.6 9.1 8.8 8.5 8.9 9.6
TE (%) 11.2 11.5 11.5 11.6 11.3 11.5 11.9
K (MPa) 414 ± 10 433 ± 1 413 ± 5 390 ± 10 415 ± 10 417 ± 10 420 ± 10
n 0.1 0.096 0.097 0.094 0.1 0.096 0.1
R 0.79 0.74 0.78 0.95 0.84 0.93 0.85
YS: yield strength; UTS, ultimate tensile strength; UE, uniform elongation; TE, total elongation (at 50 mm gauge length); K, strength coefficient; n, strain hardening coefficient; and R, plastic strain ratio.

sec.title: Welding experiments
sec.p:
Same thickness sheets of AA6061-T651 were welded together using an FSW machine designed and developed by IISc and ETA Technologies, Bangalore. FSW blanks were welded by varying the process parameters such as TRS, FR, plunge depth, and tool SD, while the tool tilt angle (2.5°) was kept constant throughout the process. In order to optimize the processing conditions, a series of experiments were conducted with different parameters to achieve the ‘internal defect free’ FSW joints. Three types of tools (Figure 1) with flat shoulder having different diameters and pin with equal PLs were used for all the welding trials. The tools were made of hot die steel with SD 12, 15, and 18 mm and pin of frustum shape with base diameter 6 mm, top diameter 4 mm, and length 1.7 mm. The FSWs were produced at TRSs 800–1600 r/min, FRs 50–130 mm/min, and plunge depth varied from 1.5 to 2.0 mm with three SDs. After welding, these parameters were optimized for defect-free welds through macrostructure analysis. A few defective and defect-free macrostructures are shown in Figure 2 (a) to (d). The optimized range of parameters is fixed at 1300–1500 r/min for TRS, 80–120 mm/min for FR, and 1.85–2.0 mm for plunge depth for all the three SDs (12, 15, and 18 mm). In this study, only the effect of rotational speeds and FRs on the forming limit is focused on. The selected parameters are given in Table 3. The FSW condition 9 is made as a third trial at rotational speed 1500 r/min and FR 120 mm/min. Figure 1.
FSW tools with different SDs with similar pin profile.
FSW: friction stir welding; SD: shoulder diameter.
Figure 2.
Macrostructures of FSW AA6061-T651 alloy joints at different process parameters with 10 × magnification: (a,b) defective welds and (c,d) defect-free welds.
FSW: friction stir welding.
Table 3.
Different optimized FSW conditions used for welding trials.
FSW conditions Rotational speed (r/min) FR (mm/min) SD (mm) Plunge depth (mm)
1 1300, 1400 90 12 1.9
2 1300, 1400 90 18 1.9
3 1300, 1400 100 12 1.9
4 1300, 1400 100 18 1.9
5 1300 90, 100 12 1.9
6 1400 90, 100 12 1.9
7 1300 90, 100 18 1.9
8 1400 90, 100 18 1.9
9 1500 120 15 1.95
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; and SD: shoulder diameter.

sec.title: Microhardness experiments
sec.p: Samples of FSW joints were polished using different grades of emery papers to measure the microhardness. The grades of emery papers were varied from 200 to1000 for polishing the FSW joints. Finally, cloth polishing was done to make the surface dents free. Microhardness profiles were taken across the welded joint at different locations on the transverse cross section of the joints. A 50 gf load was used for the Vickers microhardness measurements. Three trials were made and an averaged hardness value was used for the analysis.

sec.title: Formability testing and forming limit evaluation
sec.p:
In order to study the influence of FSW parameters, namely, rotational speed and FR, LDH formability tests were performed on the welded and unwelded blanks with load on the punch monitored by the control system, as discussed by Janaki Ramulu et al.19 The same rolling direction was maintained during the LDH tests for the unwelded and FSW sheets. Few different strain paths were dot printed with 1 mm diameter on the sheet surface. Strain path widths (100 × 200 mm2, 125 × 200 mm2, etc.) with three lubrication (dry, grease, and oil) conditions simulating six different pre-defined strain paths in the stretching side were deformed to construct an forming limit curve (FLC). The strain paths in the LDH test simulate different modes of deformation from tensile to plane strain to stretching that are seen in the stamping operations. All the blanks (both welded and unwelded) were deformed until failure (or necking) occurs and repeated twice for each condition. Load on the punch monitored by the control system is used to monitor the failure. By then, grids had deformed to ellipses. The true major strains and true minor strains of the ellipses, near and away from the failure, were measured in all the strain paths using off-line deformation system with help of GOM made ARGUS software. These major and minor strain data were plotted on a major strain (y-axis)–minor strain (x-axis) graph. All the failed strains and safe strains were incorporated in the same graph. The FLCs were plotted such that they separate all the failed strains from the safe strains. The FLD of the unwelded blank is shown in Figure 3 for illustration. In this figure, the major strain and minor strain values above the FLC are considered as failed strains and those below the FLC are safe strains. This procedure is followed for all the unwelded and welded blanks. The FLCs of the welded blanks were compared with each other and also with that of the unwelded blank to investigate the influence of the TRS and FR on the forming limit strains of the FSW blanks. The obtained limiting major strains at different FSW conditions are given in Table 4. Thickness distribution was measured on both sides of the neck toward peak of the dome with a sharp-edged micrometer perpendicular to the fracture. The thickness distribution was measured at regular intervals at the weld center, as shown in Figure 4. Three data were considered for averaging the thickness values at each location. The dome height at failure was measured using a vernier height gage for all the FSW conditions made at 100 × 200 and 125 × 200 strain paths with three different lubricants. Figure 3.
FLD of the unwelded blank.
FLD: forming limit diagram.
Figure 4.
Thickness measurement method for FSW sheets and unwelded sheets.
FSW: friction stir welding.
Table 4.
Major limit strain values of different FSW conditions.
FSW conditions Rotational speed (r/min) FR (mm/min) SD (mm) Plunge depth (mm) Limiting major strain values
Near-plane-strain strain path Biaxial stretching strain path
Unwelded blank 0.23 0.33
1 1300 90 12 1.9 0.25 0.4
1400 0.24 0.44
2 1300 100 12 1.9 0.24 0.34
1400 0.25 0.42
3 1300 90 18 1.9 0.2 0.48
1400 0.2 0.5
4 1300 100 18 1.9 0.3 0.46
1400 0.28 0.48
5 1500 120 15 1.95 0.2 0.44
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; and SD: shoulder diameter.

sec.title: Microhardness profiles of FSW sheets
sec.p:
Figures 5 and 6 show the microhardness profiles of FSW joints fabricated at different FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) and TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min). It is observed from Figure 5 that hardness values are more in the case with FR 100 mm/min compared to the FR at 90 mm/min, and also a maximum hardness of 123 VHN is found on the retreating side of the FSW joint. In both the cases, hardness values are larger in the retreating side compared to the advancing side and minimum hardness values of 96.1 and 94.4 VHN are seen at the weld nugget (WN) region. From Figure 6 it is observed that the hardness values are higher in case with rotational speed 1300 r/min as compared to 1400 r/min, and also a maximum hardness value of 118.2 VHN is found at the transition zone in the retreating side of the FSW joint. In both the rotational speeds, hardness values are more in the retreating side compared to the advancing side and minimum hardness values of 96.1 and 89.3 VHN are found at the WN in both the cases. Similarly, hardness behavior is seen in other FSW conditions (Table 4) also, wherein by increasing the FR and decreasing the rotational speed, hardness has improved. Figure 5.
Microhardness distribution of FSW joints at different FRs, 90 and 100 mm/min, at constant rotational speed 1300 r/min and plunge depth 1.9 mm using a tool of SD 12 mm.
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; SD: shoulder diameter; BM: base metal; HAZ: heat-affected zone; and WN: weld nugget.
Hardness repeatability: ± 1 to ± 2.
Figure 6.
Microhardness distribution of FSW joints at different TRSs, 1300 and 1400 r/min, corresponding to FSW condition 1 in Table 4.
FSW: friction stir welding; TRS: tool rotation speed; BM: base metal; HAZ: heat-affected zone; and WN: weld nugget.
Hardness repeatability: ± 1 to ± 2.

sec.title: Effect of TRS on forming limit of FSW blanks
sec.p:
The overall formability performance of FSW blanks in stretching deformation was investigated through LDH formability test with different lubricant conditions for the welded and unwelded sheets experimentally. Deformed unwelded blanks and FSW blanks with different lubricant conditions are shown in Figures 7 and 8 for illustration. Failure pattern in the unwelded blanks is same in all the strain paths during the LDH test, as shown Figure 7. In case of FSW blanks made at different TRSs, failure pattern in 100 × 200 mm2 strain path is perpendicular to the weld-like unwelded blanks, whereas in 125 × 200 mm2, failure is at interface of the weld, as shown in Figure 8. Figure 7.
Deformed samples of unwelded blanks at different lubrication conditions.
Figure 8.
Deformed FSW blanks at different TRSs, FR 90 mm/min and plunge depth 1.9 mm with SD 12 mm at different lubrication conditions.
FSW: friction stir welding; TRS: tool rotation speed; FR: feed rate; and SD: shoulder diameter.

The influence of the TRS under different FSW conditions (1–4 in Table 3) on FLC of FSW blanks is compared with unwelded blank FLC. Figure 9 shows the master FLD presenting the effect of TRSs on the FLCs of FSW blanks which are made using different TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min), at constant FR 90 mm/min, and plunge depth 1.9 mm with a 12 mm SD (FSW condition 1 in Table 3). It is observed that the forming limit of the unwelded blank and two FSW blanks are almost same in near-plane-strain strain path and FSW sheets formability has improved significantly in the stretching strain paths, increasing its overall formability. When FSW blank FLCs are compared, FLC at TRS 1400 r/min is better than at 1300 r/min in the stretching strain paths. The percentage difference in true major strain values between base material and FSW blank with TRS 1300 r/min is 7% and 1400 r/min is 11%. When the percentage difference is seen within the FSW blanks, about 4% difference is witnessed in the stretching side. The percentage difference is calculated from the major strain values presented in Table 4. Figure 9.
Influence of TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min) on forming limit strains at FR 90 mm/min, SD 12 mm, and plunge depth 1.9 mm.
TRS: tool rotation speed; FR: feed rate; and SD: shoulder diameter.

Likewise, it is observed from Figure 10 that the forming limit of the FSW blanks fabricated at different TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min) with 18 mm SD at a constant FR of 90 mm/min and plunge depth 1.9 mm (FSW condition 2 in Table 3) is better than the unwelded blank with a higher TRS (1400 r/min) showing a better forming limit. It is observed that the forming limit of the unwelded blank is slightly better than FSW sheets in the near-plane-strain strain path and it decreases significantly in the stretching strain paths. The percentage difference in the true major strain values between the base material and the FSW blanks is 3% approximately in the near-plane-strain stretching condition, whereas in the stretching side, TRSs 1300 and 1400 r/min showed a considerable difference of 15% and 17%, respectively. Figure 10.
Influence of TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min) on forming limit strains at FR 90 mm/min, SD 18 mm, and plunge depth 1.9 mm.
TRS: tool rotation speed; FR: feed rate; and SD: shoulder diameter.

Similar formability tests were carried out for the other two FSW conditions (3 and 4 in Table 3) with FR 100 mm/min. In general, it is found that the forming limit of FSW blank is better than that of base material. Moreover the forming limit of FSW blank made with TRS 1400 r/min is 8% more than FSW blank made with 1300 r/min (Figures 11 and 12). Similar results are observed in the case of FSW blanks made with FR 90 mm/min discussed earlier. It should be noted that for the FSW blank made at FR 90 mm/min, the forming limit in the case of FSW sheet made at 1400 r/min is 1% lesser than at 1300 r/min in the near-plane-strain condition, but improves about 4% in the stretching side (Figure 9). Figure 11.
Influence of TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min) on forming limit strains at FR 100 mm/min, SD 12 mm, and plunge depth 1.9 mm.
TRS: tool rotation speed; FR: feed rate; and SD: shoulder diameter.
Figure 12.
Influence of TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min) on forming limit strains at FR 100 mm/min, SD 18 mm, and plunge depth 1.9 mm.
TRS: tool rotation speed; FR: feed rate; and SD: shoulder diameter.

In summary, the forming limit of FSW blanks is higher than that of the base material. With increase in TRS, the forming limit is found to improve considerably, about 1–2% in the near-plane-strain condition and 2–8% in the stretching side.

sec.title: Influence of FR on forming limit of FSW blanks
sec.p:
The deformed FSW blanks made at different FRs with different lubricants are shown in Figure 13 for illustration. The failure pattern is found to be same as that of FSW sheets made at different rotation speeds. Figure 13.
Deformed FSW blanks at different FRs, TRS 1300 r/min and plunge depth 1.9 mm with SD 12 mm at different lubrication conditions.
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; TRS: tool rotation speed; and SD: shoulder diameter.

The influence of FR on the FLC of FSW blanks made at different welding conditions is compared with unwelded blank FLC in Figures 14 to 17. Figure 14 shows the master FLD presenting the effect of different FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) on the FLCs of FSW blanks which are fabricated at TRS 1300 r/min, plunge depth 1.9 mm, and tool with SD 12 mm (FSW condition 5 in Table 3). It is observed that forming limit of the FSW blanks is better than that of the unwelded blank. The percentage difference in the near-plane-strain condition between the true major strain values of the base material and FSW blanks made at FRs 90 mm/min and 100 mm/min is 2% and 1% respectively. But in the stretching side, an improvement of 7% and 1% in major limit strain is seen for FRs 90 mm/min and 100 mm/min as compared to the BM. So, with the increase in FR, the forming limit has decreased with a difference of 6% between the FSW blanks in the stretching side. Figure 14.
Influence of FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) on forming limit strains at TRS 1300 r/min, SD 12 mm, and plunge depth 1.9 mm.
FR: feed rate; TRS: tool rotation speed; and SD: shoulder diameter.
Figure 15.
Influence of FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) on forming limit strains at TRS 1300 r/min, SD 18 mm, and plunge depth 1.9 mm.
FR: feed rate; TRS: tool rotation speed; and SD: shoulder diameter.
Figure 16.
Influence of FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) on forming limit strains at TRS 1400 r/min, SD 12 mm, and plunge depth 1.9 mm.
FR: feed rate; TRS: tool rotation speed; and SD: shoulder diameter.
Figure 17.
Influence of FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) on forming limit strains at TRS 1400 r/min, SD 18 mm, and plunge depth 1.9 mm.
FR: feed rate; TRS: tool rotation speed; and SD: shoulder diameter.

Similar behavior is seen in Figure 16 for FSW condition 6 in Table 3 that with increasing FR, forming limit has decreased. It is observed that forming limit of FSW sheets made at FR 90 mm/min is same as that of the other two forming limits in the near-plane-strain strain path, but found to improve on the stretching strain path.

Similar formability tests were carried out for the other two FSW conditions (conditions 7 and 8 in Table 3) with two different TRSs. In general, it is found that the forming limit of FSW blank is better than that of the base material. Moreover, the forming limit of FSW blank made at FR 90 mm/min is better than FSW blank made at 100 mm/min. It should be noted that for FSW sheet made with 18 mm SD tool, the forming limit in the case of FSW blank at FR 90 mm/min is lower than at 100 mm/min in the near-plane-strain strain path, but improves in the stretching side, as shown in Figure 15 and 17.

To summarize, the forming limit of FSW blanks is higher than that of the base material. With increase in FR, the forming limit is found to decrease. In three cases, the forming limit of FSW blanks made at FR 100 mm/min in the near-plane-strain condition is slightly better than at 90 mm/min and considerable improvement is seen on the stretching side for FR 90 mm/min.

In the third level, FSW blank is made with a tool of 15 mm SD at rotational speed 1500 r/min, FR 120 mm/min, and plunge depth 1.95 mm (FSW condition 9 in Table 3). The overall formability of the FSW sheets is better than the unwelded blank and when FSW sheet FLCs are compared, FLC of FR 120 mm/min has lower formability than those with 90 mm/min and 100 mm/min in the stretching strain path. This comparison is shown in Figure 18. Figure 18.
FLCs of FSW blanks made at condition 9 in Table 3 and comparison with FRs 90 and 100 mm/min and unwelded sheet FLCs.
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; and FLC: forming limit curve;.

sec.title: Thinning behavior of FSW sheets and its relation with forming limit
sec.p: In general, ‘necking’ can be understood as a phenomenon occurring in sheets because of the presence of an initial thickness heterogeneity in the material, as a result of which material thinning occurs during the course of deformation or forming. The more the thinning gradient (at a particular punch travel) the earlier the limits strain will be reached, and hence, a lower formability or forming limit is expected. In the case of FSW sheets, the presence of the weld region and the properties of weld region decided by FSW parameters results in an increased or decreased thinning gradient in comparison with that of the unwelded blank. Moreover, thickness distribution during the sheet forming is an important index that quantifies the formability of the sheet material. Even in industrial practice, thinning percentage is observed for quantification of formability. A better or uniform thinning behavior implies a better formability of that particular sheet material.

In this section, an attempt has been made to relate the change in forming limit of FSW sheets with the thinning behavior during forming. The thinning behavior is evaluated by monitoring the thickness distribution after forming the FSW sheets.

sec.title: Thinning behavior of FSW blanks made at different TRSs
sec.p:
The thinning behavior of FSW blanks made at different TRSs in comparison to that of the unwelded blank is presented in Figures 19 to 22. The thickness is measured normal to the necked region using a micrometer with reference to the dot grids marked on the deformed at an interval of 2.5 mm sheet surface, as shown in Figure 4. The averaged thickness data are recorded at a point for three repetitions. Figure 19 shows the thickness distribution of unwelded blank and FSW blanks made at FSW condition 1 in Table 3. It is observed that FSW blanks made at 1300 r/min and 1400 r/min have lesser thinning gradient as compared to unwelded blank near fracture. This resulted in reduced FLC for the unwelded blanks when compared with FSW blanks, as shown in Figure 9. The uniformity in the thinning gradient of unwelded blank and FSW blanks can be understood from Figure 20. It is seen that thinning gradient is very sensitive in the fracture region. There is a sudden change in the thickness variation in all the cases because of necking, and hence, a sudden and localized shoot up is observed in the thickness difference. When thickness difference is observed among the three blanks, unwelded blank has more thickness difference, of 0.47 mm, near the fracture; whereas in FSW blanks, 1300 r/min has more thickness difference, of 0.20 mm, as compared to 1400 r/min case which exhibits a thickness difference of 0.18 mm. This implies that FSW blanks made at TRS 1400 r/min exhibit uniform thickness distribution as compared to the other two cases. The uniform thickness distribution has improved the forming limit of FSW blanks made at TRS 1400 r/min, as shown in Figure 9. Figure 19.
Comparison of experimental thickness distribution of FSW blanks made at different rotational speeds (1300 and 1400 r/min) using 12 mm tool SD at plunge depth 1.9 mm and FR 90 mm/min to unwelded blank in the LDH test.
FSW: friction stir welding; SD: shoulder diameter; FR: feed rate; and LDH: limit dome height.
Figure 20.
Comparison of thickness gradient uniformity of FSW blanks of different TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min) at FR 90 mm/min to unwelded blank.
FSW: friction stir welding; TRS: tool rotation speed; and FR: feed rate.
Figure 21.
Comparison of experimental thickness distribution of FSW blanks made at different rotational speeds (1300 and 1400 r/min) using 18 mm tool SD at plunge depth 1.9 mm and FR 90 mm/min to unwelded blank in the LDH test.
FSW: friction stir welding; SD: shoulder diameter; FR: feed rate; and LDH: limit dome height.
Figure 22.
Comparison of thickness gradient uniformity of FSW blanks of different TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min) at FR 90 mm/min to unwelded blank.
FSW: friction stir welding; TRS: tool rotation speed; and FR: feed rate.

Figure 21 shows the other case on thinning behavior comparison of unwelded blank with FSW blanks made using condition 2 in Table 3 with different rotational speeds. In this case also, it is observed that unwelded blanks has more thinning gradient than FSW blanks; whereas in FSW blanks, 1300 r/min case has more thinning gradient than 1400 r/min case near the fracture irrespective of other process parameters. When the thickness difference (Figure 22) is observed, the unwelded blanks has more thickness difference (0.47 mm) near the fracture; whereas in FSW blanks, 1300 r/min case has more thickness difference (0.16 mm) as compared to 1400 r/min rotational speed.

Similar observations are seen in other FSW conditions 3 and 4 in Table 3 that thinning gradient is more for the unwelded blank than the FSW blanks. FSW sheet made at a rotational speed of 1300 r/min has more thinning gradient than the FSW blank made at 1400 r/min. Thinning gradient sensitivity is more for a rotational speed of 1300 r/min in all the cases as compared to 1400 r/min. Because of this, the overall formability of unwelded blank and FSW sheet made at 1300 r/min has reduced as compared to FSW sheets made at 1400 r/min.

sec.title: Thinning behavior of FSW blanks made at different FRs
sec.p:
The thinning behavior of FSW blanks in comparison with that of unwelded blank by considering the variable FR is presented in Figures 23 to 26. Figure 23 shows the thickness distribution of unwelded blank and FSW blanks with FSW condition 5 in Table 3 at different FRs 90 and 100 mm/min. It is observed that FSW blanks made at FRs 90 mm/min and 100 mm/min have minimum thinning gradient as compared to the unwelded blank near fracture. This resulted in reduced FLC for the unwelded blanks when compared to FSW blanks at FRs 90 mm and 100 mm/min, as shown in Figure 13. The uniformity in thinning gradient of the unwelded blank and FSW blanks can be understood from Figure 24, which shows that the thinning gradient from one end to other end of unwelded blank and FSW blanks is almost similar except near the necked region. When the thickness difference is observed among the three blanks, unwelded blank has more thickness difference (0.47 mm) near the fracture; whereas FSW blanks at FRs 90 mm/min and 100 mm/min have 0.19 mm and 0.24 mm (Figure 24). This basically has reflected in the forming limit, as shown in Figure 13. Similar results are seen in the case of FSW conditions 6 to 8 in Table 3 that the thinning gradient is more for unwelded blank than FSW blanks at different FRs, and FSW blanks made at FR 100 mm/min has more thinning gradient than that made at 90 mm/min (Figures 25 and 26 for FSW condition 8). Figure 23.
Comparison of experimental thickness distribution of FSW blanks made at different FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) using 12 mm tool SD at plunge depth 1.9 mm and rotational speed of 1300 r/min to unwelded blank in the LDH test.
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; SD: shoulder diameter; and LDH: limit dome height.
Figure 24.
Comparison of thickness gradient uniformity of FSW blanks of different FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) at TRS 1300 r/min to unwelded blank.
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; and TRS: tool rotation speed.
Figure 25.
Comparison of experimental thickness distribution of FSW blanks made at different FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) using 18 mm tool SD at plunge depth 1.9 mm and rotational speed of 1400 r/min to unwelded blank in the LDH test.
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; SD: shoulder diameter; and LDH: limit dome height.
Figure 26.
Comparison of thickness gradient uniformity of FSW blanks of different FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) at TRS 1400 r/min to unwelded blank.
FSW: friction stir welding; FR: feed rate; and TRS: tool rotation speed.

sec.title: Effect of TRS and FR on strain hardening coefficient (n) and its relation with forming limit of FSW blanks
sec.p:
The strain hardening coefﬁcient influences the strain distribution in a forming operation. Increasing ‘n’ values distribute the strain and thickness uniformly in the sheets during forming. If strain distribution is uniform, then FLC is likely to improve. For example, Figure 27(a) shows the thickness distribution of a sheet made of a standard steel grade and Figure 27(b) the thickness distribution of a sheet made of 6061 aluminum alloy formed at biaxial stretching strain path having different ‘n’ values by keeping all other properties constant (namely, Young’s modulus, Poisson’s ratio, density and plastic strain ratio) with initial sheet thickness of 2 mm. The input data of ‘n’ for standard steel and aluminum alloy was taken from the available data.20–23 The standard LDH test was simulated in PAM STAMP 2 G for each blank. The base material blank was comprised of quadrilateral shell elements of Belytschko–Tsay formulation with five through-thickness integration points. Hollomon’s strain hardening law and Hill’s 1948 isotropic hardening yield criterion was used as the plasticity model. This thickness distribution is measured perpendicular to the failure at same punch travel before failure. It is observed from Figure 27 that a sheet with n = 0.3 exhibits uniform thickness distribution when comaperd to the case with n = 0.15. Similar result is observed for Al alloy sheet also. So, improvement in ‘n’ value improves the thickness distribution uniformity during sheet forming. Figure 27.
Thickness distribution of unwelded sheet at different ‘n’ values at same punch travel.

The strain hardening coefficient (n) of FSW region was evaluated through tensile tests using samples containing weld zone only, as shown in Figure 28. These tests performed were similar to that of base material property evaluation.24 Table 5 summarizes the strain hardening exponent values obtained from tensile test of FSW blanks with longitudinal weld made at variable welding conditions. The values represents ‘n’ value of the weld zone only. Figure 28.
(a) Schematic representation of FSW tensile sample with only weld zone and (b) FSW tested tensile sample of 18 mm weld width.
FSW: friction stir welding.
Table 5.
Strain hardening coefficient (n) values of weld zone at different FSW conditions with variable SDs.
FSW conditions TRS (r/min) FR (mm/min) SD (mm) Plunge depth (mm) Strain hardening coefficient (n)
Unwelded blank 0.1
1 1300 90 12 1.9 0.24
1400 0.25
2 1300 100 12 1.9 0.25
1400 0.25
3 1300 90 18 1.9 0.27
1400 0.3
4 1300 100 18 1.9 0.26
1400 0.28
5 1500 120 15 1.95 0.27
FSW: friction stir welding; TRS: tool rotation speed; FR: feed rate; SD: shoulder diameter.
Error variation in ‘n’ values: ± 0.002–0.004.

From the earlier sections, it is observed that FSW blanks of higher TRS exhibit better FLC and lesser thinning gradient. It is observed from Table 5 that the weld zone made at TRS 1400 r/min exhibits higher ‘n’ value than 1300 r/min at any FR and unwelded blank. This has resulted in better FLC for FSW blanks made with TRS 1400 r/min compared to 1300 r/min and unwelded sheet. It should be noted that the n-value of the weld zone made at 1500 r/min is in between ‘n’ values obtained for 1300 r/min and 1400 r/min. But in few cases, it is almost same as that of values obtained for 1400 r/min. The error variation in ‘n’ values for different trials at same conditions is between ± 0.002 and ± 0.004, which is very small as compared to change in ‘n’ values at different welding conditions. Moreover, there is about 50% increase in ‘n’ values between unwelded and FSW sheets, and about 5–12% improvement between different FSW conditions. Hence, the change in ‘n’ values is found to be significant, affecting the forming limit of FSW sheets.

The effect of FR on the strain hardening exponent of the weld zone is illustrated in Table 5. It is observed that with increase in FR from 90 to 100 mm/min, the strain hardening exponent is found to decrease, for the same rotational speed. As the TRS increases or the FR reduces, the temperature in the stirring zone is expected to increase. This means that the final grain size would be larger25 and it is also expected that the dislocation density reduces as the temperature increases. It leads to more static recrystallization in the WN region. Strain hardening behavior is typically related to the accumulation and interaction of the dislocations. If the dislocation density is lower, more strain can be induced in the material, thus increasing the ductility and so its forming limit has improved. In contrast, in the BM, the saturation of the dislocation density results in the lower strain hardening exponent and poor ductility, resulting in less formability.26–29

sec.title: Effect of TRS and FR on dome height
sec.p:
Table 6 presents the dome height comparison of all FSW sheets deformed at different strain paths using different lubricants (dry, oil, and grease). It is observed that dome height of FSW blanks is more compared to the unwelded blank in the near-plane-strain strain path, whereas in 125 × 200 mm2 strain path, unwelded blank has more dome height than all FSW sheets. This is mainly due to the failure occuring in the weld region parallel to the major strain direction in the stretching strain paths. However, in the case of near-plane-strain strain path, failure is witnessed normal to the weld region. It is also observed that there is not much variation in the dome height with respect to varied FR and TRS, unlike in forming limit curve and thickness distribution. There is hardly 1–2 mm variation in dome height in all FSW cases and at different lubricant conditions. Table 6.
Dome height of FSW blanks at different FSW conditions.
FSW conditions TRS (r/min) FR (mm/min) SD (mm) Plunge depth (mm) Dome height (mm) at varied strain paths
100 × 200 mm2 125 × 200 mm2
Dry Oil Grease Dry Oil Grease
Base material 27.1 27.04 27.02 28 28.08 28
1 1300 90 12 1.9 29.1 28.02 29 19.1 19.12 17.18
1400 29.2 28.1 28.14 19.2 19.14 17.16
2 1300 100 12 1.9 28.1 27.14 28.14 19.1 18.14 17.08
1400 28.1 29.06 29.12 19.2 17.096 17.09
3 1300 90 18 1.9 28.2 28.14 28.1 19 19.08 17.1
1400 29.1 29.06 30.16 19.2 17.16 18.06
4 1300 100 18 1.9 29 29.18 30.02 19.2 18.1 21
1400 29.1 30.1 28.06 21.1 20.08 18.18
5 1500 120 15 1.95 31.1 29.12 29.12 23.1 18.16 17.06
FSW: friction stir welding; TRS: tool rotation speed; FR: feed rate; and SD: shoulder diameter.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The following are the conclusions made from the present analyses.
The FSW sheets made at different FRs (90 and 100 mm/min) and at different TRSs (1300 and 1400 r/min) exhibit higher forming limit as compared to unwelded sheets.
By increasing the TRS from 1300 to 1400 r/min, for a constant FR (either at 90 or 100 mm/min), the formability of FSW blank is found to improve. When FR is increased from 90 to 100 mm/min, for a constant TRS (either at 1300 or 1400 r/min), the forming limit of FSW blanks has decreased. It has been demonstrated that this is mainly due to the evolution of thickness gradient during forming/necking of FSW sheets and change in strain hardening exponent of weld region.
The thickness gradient during forming near the necked region is found to be severe in unwelded blanks as compared to FSW blanks, because of which the forming limit is improved for FSW sheets. Similar observations were made in the case of FSW sheets produced at higher FR and lower TRS.
There is an increase in the strain hardening exponent (n) of the weld region with increase in TRS from 1300 to 1400 r/min and decrease in FR from 100 to 90 mm/min. As the TRS increases, for a constant FR, or as the FR reduces, for a constant TRS, the temperature in the stirring zone is expected to increase. Then, the final grain size would be larger and also the dislocation density reduces as the temperature increases. Strain hardening behavior is typically related the dislocations. If the dislocation density is lower, more strain can be induced in the material, thus increasing the ductility and so its forming limit has improved.
There is not much variation in the dome height among the welded sheets. There is hardly 1–2 mm variation in the dome height in all FSW cases. In the stretching strain paths, the dome height of the welded sheets is lower than that of the base material.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work has been funded by Department of Science and Technology (DST), India.
